'''Kalyanapuram Rangachari Parthasarathy''' (born 25 June 1936) is professor emeritus at the [[Indian Statistical Institute]] and a pioneer of [[quantum stochastic calculus]].

==Biography==
He was born in 1936 <ref name="Seventy-fifth birthday">{{cite web|last=[[Kalyan Bidhan Sinha]] and [[B. V. Rajarama Bhat]]|title=Professor K. R. Parthasarathy|url=https://www.math.lsu.edu/cosa/6-1-00%5Bpartha%5D.pdf|publisher=[[Louisiana State University]]}}</ref><ref name="Conferring on D.Sc degree">{{cite web|title=Conferring on him the degree of Doctor of Sciences|url=http://www.cmi.ac.in/events/honoris-causa/parthasarathy|publisher=[[Chennai Mathematical Institute]]}}</ref> at [[Chennai]]. He studied at the [[Ramakrishna Mission Vivekananda College]], where he completed the B.A. (Honours)
course in [[Mathematics]], and moved to the [[Indian Statistical Institute]], [[Kolkata]], where he completed his Ph.D., under the supervision of [[C. R. Rao]] in 1962. He was one of the "famous four" (the others were [[R. Ranga Rao]], [[Veeravalli S. Varadarajan]], and [[S. R. Srinivasa Varadhan]] ) in [[Indian Statistical Institute|ISI]] during 1956-1963. He was awarded the first Ph.D. degree of ISI.<ref name="Seventy-fifth birthday" /> He won the [[Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize]] for Science and Technology in Mathematical Science in 1977.

==Research==
He worked at the [[Steklov Mathematical Institute]], [[USSR Academy of Sciences]] (1962–63), as Lecturer where he collaborated  with [[Andrey Kolmogorov]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Professor KR Parthasarathy|url=http://insaindia.org/detail.php?id=n76-0553|publisher=[[Indian National Science Academy]]}}</ref> Later he came in [[United Kingdom]] as Professor of Statistics in [[University of Sheffield]] (1964–68),  [[University of Manchester]] (1968-70)  and later at [[University of Nottingham]] where he collaborated  with [[Robin Lyth Hudson]] on their pioneering work in quantum stochastic calculus.<ref name="Conferring on D.Sc degree" /><ref>{{cite web|last=D Applebaum|title=Robin Hudson's Pathless Path to Quantum Stochastic Calculus|url=https://www.applebaum.staff.shef.ac.uk/Hudpath.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Jinqiao Duan, Shunlong Luo, Caishi Wang|title=Recent development in stochastic dynamics and stochastic analysis|year=2010|publisher=World Scientific|isbn=9814277266|page=preface-x}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=K. R. Parthasarathy|title=Quantum Stochastic Calculus|url=https://www.mathunion.org/Publications/Bulletins/39/parthasarathy.ps}}</ref> Then he returned to India, and after a few years in [[Bombay University]] and the [[Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi]], he came back in 1976 to the new [[Indian Statistical Institute, Delhi Centre]] and he stayed there till he retired in 1996.<ref name="Seventy-fifth birthday" />

He is the namesake of [[Kostant–Parthasarathy–Ranga Rao–Varadarajan determinants]] along with [[Bertram Kostant]], [[R. Ranga Rao]] and [[Veeravalli S. Varadarajan]] which they introduced in 1967.<ref>K. R. Parthasarathy, R. Ranga Rao, and [[Veeravalli S. Varadarajan]]. "Representations of complex semi-simple Lie groups and Lie algebras." The Annals of Mathematics 85.3 (1967): 383-429</ref>

==Books authored==
Among the books he has authored are:
* K. R. Parthasarathy. Probability measures on metric spaces. Vol. 352. American Mathematical Soc., 1967.
* [[Robin Lyth Hudson]], and K. R. Parthasarathy. "Quantum Ito's formula and stochastic evolutions." Communications in Mathematical Physics 93.3 (1984): 301-323.
* K. R. Parthasarathy. An introduction to quantum stochastic calculus. Vol. 85. Springer, 1992.
* K. R. Parthasarathy, and [[Klaus Schmidt]]. "Positive definite kernels, continuous tensor products, and central limit theorems of probability theory (series: lecture notes in mathematics)." (1972).
